module.name: strategy/pack/common
module.description:
This module defines generic strategies for packing a set of modules reachable from a root module and for flattening a set of modules into a single program.
Module systems allow the definition of a program to be split into separate units stored in separate files. For languages that do not support separate compilation (such as grammar formalisms) these separate units need to be combined to create the whole program.
Aspects of module packing and flattening
- finding the module associated with the module name - doing something with the module, i.e., adding it to the result - finding the imports in a module - keeping track of which modules have already been inlined

strategy.name: pack
strategy.description: Packing a module consists of collecting all modules into a single file.

strategy.name: unpack
strategy.description: Unpacking is the reverse of packing, i.e., writing each module in a list of modules to a separate file.

strategy.name: flatten
strategy.description: <flatten> (root, mods)| produces a flattened version of the root module.
